title: Rescuers press on for a third day as families of the missing wait in anguish.
description: As the sun rose on Saturday, rescue workers entered the third day of an increasingly desperate search for anyone who might still be alive within the giant pile of broken concrete and twisted metal that once was a condominium building north of Miami Beach.
content: As the sun rose on Saturday, rescue workers entered the third day of an increasingly desperate search for anyone who might still be alive within the giant pile of broken concrete and twisted metal that once was a condominium building north of Miami Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $730,000 Homes in California
description: A 1914 cottage in Sonoma, a bungalow in Oakland and a one-bedroom condominium in Santa Monica.
content: This house is a few blocks from a stretch of Sonoma Highway, the city’s main road, that is populated by food trucks, coffee shops and casual restaurants. The surrounding area is famous for wine production, and several vineyards, including Amapola Creek and Hanzell Vineyards, are nearby. Fairmont Sonoma Mission Inn and Spa, known for its geothermal hot springs, is half a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Case for a 32-Team Euros
description: Given the depth of quality in Europe, a small expansion (and a simpler format) could make for a much better tournament.
content: LONDON — Thomas Vermaelen’s header hit the ground first and then rose before colliding with the post near the corner where it meets the crossbar. As the ball spun out, sideways toward the middle of the goal, Lukas Hradecky, the Finland goalkeeper, was still turning around. It was all happening in the blink of an eye. Instinctively, Hradecky reached out a hand to try to swat the ball away. In that instant, on his fingertips, a substantial portion of Euro 2020 hung.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wilson
title: The Cryonics Industry Would Like to Give You the Past Year, and Many More, Back
description: The business of cryopreservation — storing bodies at deep freeze until well into the future — got a whole lot more complicated during the pandemic.
content: When an 87-year-old Californian man was wheeled into an operating room just outside Phoenix last year, the pandemic was at its height and medical protocols were being upended across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Diagramless
description: Alex Eaton-Salners guides us to a state of amazement.
content: DIAGRAMLESS — There are a couple of ways to tackle the diagramless variety puzzle, where you get your clues and your grid and all you know is that all of the first things somehow fit into the second thing. If you’re solving from The Times Magazine, you can peek and get the first square. If not, I tried to come up with a hint in a link, which serves as a little boost (honestly, it’s really just telling you which direction to run at the start of a race, it’s hardly cheating).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Gravity’s Rainbow
description: Ross Trudeau and Lindsey Hobbs conspire in vivid colors; we’ll find the right answers.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I imagine that the intersecting set of Sunday crossword puzzle solvers and Thomas Pynchon lovers (or likers, or maybe just knowers) is pretty large, so maybe you got a little buzz like I did when you saw the title of this puzzle. If you’re not in that set, or if you are and you missed the title, “Gravity’s Rainbow,” there’s really no harm done — missing it doesn’t detract from this kaleidoscopic solve, and the meaning of the phrase here is a lot more cheerful than it is in the novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Petersen
title: Black Restaurant Week Arrives in New York
description: For the second year, Black-owned food businesses get a boost with a 10-day-long celebration featuring specials and events.
content: Black Restaurant Week has kicked off in metropolitan New York, with more than 130 Black-owned food related businesses in the tristate area offering special menu items and holding events. “For the restaurants, this is just another way to showcase the excellence we see in our community that often gets overlooked,” said Falayn Ferrell, a founder of the Black Restaurant Week organization, which runs similar events throughout the year in 14 other areas across the country. Since its founding in 2016, the organization has moved beyond just restaurants to showcase all kinds of businesses, from food trucks to caterers to bakeries. Specials can be found on the list of participants, and New Yorkers will be able to vote for their favorites in the inaugural Black Plate Awards. At the Boogie Down Grind cafe in Hunts Point in the Bronx, the owner Majora Carter added live music for a Saturday night event. She decided to participate this year after hearing about last year’s campaign. The exposure has generated better business for the cafe, Ms. Carter said. “On this 100th anniversary of the Tulsa massacre, it’s so important we establish the value of support for all Black-owned businesses,” Ms. Carter said. “It’s time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: In France’s Military, Muslims Find a Tolerance That Is Elusive Elsewhere
description: In a nation wary of the growth of Islam, France’s military has embraced and integrated its Muslim soldiers by facilitating their religious practice.
content: DEIR KIFA, Lebanon — Gathered in a small mosque on a French military base in southern Lebanon, six soldiers in uniform stood with their heads bowed as their imam led them in prayer next to a white wall with framed paintings of Quranic verses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Is This Railroad for the Rich?
description: To justify its big investment in the L.I.R.R., New York needs to force Long Island communities to make room for more housing.
content: Garden City, a leafy chunk of suburban Long Island, is served by four train stations on the Hempstead Branch of the Long Island Rail Road. Residents can reach New York’s Penn Station in less than 45 minutes. Next year, thanks to billions of dollars in public spending, L.I.R.R. trains will start running to Grand Central Terminal, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Trae Young Plays Like He’s a Great Shooter. The Bucks Should Let Him.
description: Young, the Atlanta Hawks guard, isn’t the 3-point threat that you would think, considering how many deep shots he takes.
content: When it comes to Giannis Antetokounmpo, the Milwaukee Bucks star, much of the discussion is about whether he takes too many 3-pointers at the expense of his true strengths, which include his dominance in the paint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Italy Shows Some Grit Just as the Results Start to Matter
description: A team that was told to have fun by its coach held its nerve in a tense, extra-time victory over Austria at Euro 2020.
content: LONDON — The crucial first touch for the opening goal, the one that brought everything that followed into existence, came not from one of the traditional parts of a body used to control a ball — the foot, sometimes the head, maybe the chest — but from something a little more unorthodox. Federico Chiesa had to improvise, so he used his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: The Unlikely Survival of the 1,081-Year-Old Tree That Gave Palo Alto Its Name
description: A redwood tree called El Palo Alto has long served as the 120-foot-tall symbol of Palo Alto, but a project to help it thrive has been delayed.
content: PALO ALTO, Calif. — It could have toppled long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Fight and Flight: T.S.A. to Resume Self-Defense Classes for Airline Crews
description: The classes, which will resume in July, come as crew members struggle with a surge in cases of unruly passengers.
content: The Transportation Security Administration will once again offer self-defense classes to flight attendants and pilots as the airline industry deals with a surge in cases of unruly passengers and sometimes violent behavior on flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Progressives’ Urgent Question: How to Win Over Voters of Color
description: A yearslong challenge for the left was starkly illustrated this week as its hopes faded in the New York mayor’s race.
content: Can progressives win broad numbers of the Black and brown voters they say their policies will benefit most?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Islanders Quietly Close Their Door to the Stanley Cup Finals
description: Seeking their first trip to the championship round since 1984, the Isles took just 18 shots on goal in a loss to Tampa Bay, the Cup’s current owners.
content: The years drift by, the players, coaches and owners come and go, and the Islanders’ long wait for another appearance in the Stanley Cup finals continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amber Tamblyn
title: Amber Tamblyn: Britney Spears’s Raw Anger, and Mine
description: What I know about the toxic combination of money and fame for young women.
content: In 2007, Britney Spears, pop icon, went to a hair salon in a Los Angeles suburb, and buzzed her head bald. I knew the salon. I’d driven past it many times — it was just over the hill from my house. Later, she would take an umbrella to a photographer’s car while members of the paparazzi strobed away, a thousand flashing camera lights forever archiving her private hell for all the world to scrutinize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Stacy Cowley and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden’s Push for Equity in Government Hits Legal and Political Roadblocks
description: No part of President Biden’s agenda has been as ambitious as his attempt to place concerns about equity squarely at the center of the federal government’s decision-making.
content: WASHINGTON — Since taking office 157 days ago, President Biden has promised to put racial equity at the center of everything he does, pledging in an executive order on Day 1 to take a “systematic approach to embedding fairness in decision-making” as he drafts legislation, hires staff, proposes spending and develops regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Sydney, Australia, enters full lockdown for the first time in the pandemic to fight the Delta variant.
description: A cluster that began with an airport limousine driver has jumped to nearly 100 cases, with dozens more expected over the coming days.
content: With an outbreak of the Delta variant spreading rapidly, Australian officials on Saturday introduced a strict two-week lockdown for all of greater Sydney and the regions surrounding the nation’s largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: There Are Jobs in the Hamptons. If Only Workers Could Afford The Rent.
description: Unable to staff shifts, some restaurants and shops, already reeling from lockdown closures, are suspending service during the lucrative summer season.
content: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y. — At the Candy Kitchen diner on Main Street, the staff juggling orders of pancakes is short by seven members — and not one job seeker has dropped off a résumé this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Johnson & Johnson to Pay New York $230 Million to Settle Opioid Case
description: The settlement agreement came just days before opening arguments in a sweeping trial of several defendants, including the company.
content: Johnson & Johnson will pay New York State more than $230 million in a settlement that also ensures the company will permanently stay out of the opioid business in the United States, the state attorney general’s office announced on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rescue workers find a body and human remains, bringing death toll to 5.
description: The number of people still unaccounted for is 156. The mayor of Miami-Dade County said three bodies have been identified.
content: Search and rescue workers at the site of the deadly collapse of the Champlain Towers South condominium building in Surfside, Fla., found one body and other human remains on Saturday evening, bringing the confirmed death toll to five, with 156 people still unaccounted for, according to Mayor Daniella Levine Cava of Miami-Dade County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: 5 Dead in Hot-Air Balloon Crash in New Mexico, Police Say
description: Four people died at the scene and a fifth person died later at a hospital, Mayor Tim Keller of Albuquerque said.
content: Five people died after a hot-air balloon crashed into a power line in Albuquerque on Saturday morning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Summer’s Bounty
description: Make the most of the season’s produce with a light pasta salad or a simple cobbler.
content: Planning a trip to the produce aisle or farmers’ market this weekend? Pick up some of the best this season has to offer — bell peppers, basil, zucchini, blueberries — and put them to work with a New York Times Cooking recipe. Kay Chun’s orzo salad with peppers and feta (above), Steven Raichlen’s grilled zucchini ribbons and Chez Panisse’s blueberry cobbler would make for an inspired summer spread. Throw in Melissa Clark’s new and already popular recipe for spinach dip, and it’ll really be a party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Strong Opening for ‘Fast & Furious’ Film Suggests Movie Crowd Is Back
description: “F9: The Fast Saga,” the ninth installment of the franchise, is expected to earn $68 million this weekend, a respectable box-office result even by prepandemic standards.
content: Is the box office back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Frustration Mounts in Search for Survivors of Condo Collapse Near Miami
description: No survivors were found Friday, and the number of people unaccounted for rose to more than 150. Their families were increasingly losing hope.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — By the time yet another fire broke out amid the dusty wreckage of the partially collapsed Champlain Towers South condo complex near Miami Beach on Friday, firefighters working with search-and-rescue crews in a desperate attempt to find survivors made an unusual decision: They would not immediately put the fire out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can My Building Ask Residents for Proof of Vaccination?
description: It’s noble for co-op boards to try to keep their shareholders safe, but they are not in a good position to police residents.
content: Q: Almost immediately after Gov. Cuomo lifted coronavirus restrictions, my Manhattan co-op ended its mask requirement in common areas and fully reopened the gym. The new rules say that people who are not fully vaccinated must still wear a mask, but how could anyone possibly know who is vaccinated and who isn’t? Should the co-op require residents to show their vaccination status? Should the board ask buyers at the board interview if they’ve been vaccinated before they approve them to live in the building?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Colosseum Opens Its Belly to the Public
description: The underground warren where ancient Roman gladiators and animals awaited their fates has been restored.
content: ROME — For nearly 450 years, the majestic amphitheater known today as the Colosseum provided spectacular, often gory, entertainment for legions of ancient Romans, and this week, archaeologists opened its restored warren of underground corridors to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: As Parents Forbid Covid Shots, Defiant Teenagers Seek Ways to Get Them
description: Most medical consent laws require parental permission for minors to get a vaccine. Now some places are easing restrictions for Covid shots while others are proposing new ones.
content: Teenagers keep all sorts of secrets from their parents. Drinking. Sex. Lousy grades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks
title: As Sudan Stumbles Toward Peace, a Standoff Over Corpses Is the Latest Obstacle
description: The Sudanese deposed a dictator, but some fear true stability can never come until the truth is revealed about who killed more than a hundred protesters.
content: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Two years after more than 100 young Sudanese were killed in a revolution that toppled a dictator, their bodies lie in limbo in a corner of the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: England opens walk-in vaccination sites as the U.K. grapples with a Delta-driven spike in cases.
description: LONDON  — The U.K. on Saturday recorded its most new coronavirus infections since early February as the National Health Service ran a “grab a jab” initiative to further drive up vaccination rates.
content: LONDON  — The U.K. on Saturday recorded its most new coronavirus infections since early February as the National Health Service ran a “grab a jab” initiative to further drive up vaccination rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Next Year, Brits Will Fly Abroad. For Now, It’s Bognor Bingo.
description: With flying discouraged, vacation spots that had been fading and unfashionable are having a moment.
content: BOGNOR REGIS, England — Little has changed in the 40 years that Jean Sheppard has been calling numbers at Crown Bingo here in the heart of Bognor Regis, one of Britain’s oldest seaside resort towns, about 60 miles south of London. The regulars still line up before the doors open at 11 a.m., hoping to nab their upholstered seat of choice in a converted cinema built in the ’30s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear
title: ‘Not My Intent’: How Biden’s Impromptu Comments Upended a Political Win
description: President Biden walked back his stray remarks in a bid to salvage an infrastructure agreement that could cement his legacy as a bipartisan deal maker.
content: WASHINGTON — It was all going according to President Biden’s tightrope plan to pass the most ambitious economic agenda in generations. Right until the moment that Mr. Biden, a politician with a history of rogue comments, veered off script.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Biden Says Afghans Must ‘Decide Their Future’ as U.S. Troops Withdraw
description: Mr. Biden told President Ashraf Ghani that the United States would still offer security assistance, as well as diplomatic and humanitarian aid.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said Friday that the future of Afghanistan was in its own hands, but he promised its president, Ashraf Ghani, that the United States would support the country even after American forces withdraw following nearly 20 years of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph B. Treaster
title: What of the sister tower to the fallen Florida condo building?
description: The mayor of Surfside, Fla., said he was not “philosophically comfortable” ordering the evacuation of the building to the north.
content: In the hours immediately after much of the Champlain Towers South condominiums collapsed, the authorities evacuated two nearby buildings, an 18-story condominium tower and a seven-story hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Richard Williams
title: They Came to Slay: L.G.B.T.Q. Trailblazers
description: These artists, activists, entrepreneurs and mentors have been leading the way and opening doors for other L.G.B.T.Q. people of color for more than 30 years. And they have no plans to stop.
content: L.G.B.T.Q. people unite every June, Pride Month, to celebrate milestones like the Stonewall uprising and the activists who have made significant contributions to the advancement of gay rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Ephrat Livni
title: Crypto’s Top V.C. Is Playing the Long Game
description: Katie Haun, a co-chair of Andreessen Horowitz’s new $2.2 billion crypto fund, is betting that the blockchain will be as big as the internet.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
title: 1+1=4? Latin America Confronts a Pandemic Education Crisis.
description: With economies reeling and millions cut off from the classroom, Latin America’s students are leaving school in alarming numbers, experts say.
content: SOACHA, Colombia — Already, two of Gloria Vásquez’s children had dropped out of school during the pandemic, including her 8-year-old, Ximena, who had fallen so far behind that she struggled with the most basic arithmetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
title: Beyond the Politics of Communion, a 2,000-Year-Old Holy Mystery
description: For many Catholics, the eucharist is something wholly apart from partisan skirmishes. It is quite literally about God.
content: WASHINGTON — It was early Wednesday evening at the adoration chapel at St. Clare’s Convent, home to the Sisters of Life in northeast Washington. Light streamed through the blue and yellow glass windows, fading in and out with the clouds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Serwer
title: The Cruel Logic of the Republican Party, Before and After Trump
description: Why there was Trumpism long before Trump — and there will be long afterward.
content: Donald Trump has claimed credit for any number of things he benefited from but did not create, and the Republican Party’s reigning ideology is one of them: a politics of cruelty and exclusion that strategically exploits vulnerable Americans by portraying them as an existential threat, against whom acts of barbarism and disenfranchisement become not only justified but worthy of celebration. This approach has a long history in American politics. The most consistent threat to our democracy has always been the drive of some leaders to restrict its blessings to a select few.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Race and History Wars
description: What progressives want, and what conservatives are fighting.
content: The debate over how American schools should teach about race and racial history has reached a curious juncture, in which it’s becoming hard to tell what the argument is about.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Skull May Point to New Kind of Ancient Human
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 26, 2021.
content: “It’s very rare to find a fossil like this, with a face in good condition. You dream of finding this stuff.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Anjali Singhvi and Patricia Mazzei
title: Engineer Warned of ‘Major Structural Damage’ at Florida Condo Complex
description: A consultant in 2018 urged the managers to repair cracked columns and crumbling concrete. The work was finally about to get underway when the building collapsed.
content: Three years before the deadly collapse of the Champlain Towers South condominium complex near Miami, a consultant found alarming evidence of “major structural damage” to the concrete slab below the pool deck and “abundant” cracking and crumbling of the columns, beams and walls of the parking garage under the 13-story building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Eduardo Medina
title: Bystander Who Intervened in Shooting of Officer Was Fatally Shot by Police
description: The police in Arvada, Colo., said a good Samaritan who fatally shot a gunman who had just killed a police officer was himself shot by responding officers.
content: A bystander who intervened in the shooting of a police officer in Colorado on Monday by shooting the gunman was himself fatally shot by a responding police officer, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Jeanne Lamon, Who Led an Early-Music Ensemble, Dies at 71
description: A violinist, she directed Tafelmusik for 33 years, striving not only to present centuries-old music as it was originally heard but also to reach modern audiences.
content: Jeanne Lamon, an accomplished violinist who was music director of the Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra and Chamber Choir for 33 years, helping to build it into one of the world’s most acclaimed baroque ensembles, died on June 20 in Victoria, British Columbia. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: What Does Eric Adams, Working-Class Champion, Mean for the Democrats?
description: Mr. Adams, who ran a campaign focused on appealing to blue-collar Black and Latino voters, said America does not want “fancy candidates.”
content: He bluntly challenged left-wing leaders in his party over matters of policing and public safety. He campaigned heavily in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, often ignoring Manhattan neighborhoods besides Harlem and Washington Heights. And he branded himself a blue-collar candidate with a keen personal understanding of the challenges and concerns facing working-class New Yorkers of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Vaccines are a tough sell in the sparsely populated, skeptical Mountain West.
description: The U.S. region includes states with some of the lowest vaccination rates in the country, rivaling the South. Many factors are at work, experts say.
content: The Mountain West has emerged as one of the most vaccine-hesitant regions of the United States. Along with the South, it is lagging far behind the national vaccination pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Paulo Mendes da Rocha, Architect of ‘Concrete Acrobatics,’ Dies at 92
description: He belonged to a group of architects known for a muscular style often called Brazilian Brutalism, but he had a lighter touch than that label implies.
content: Paulo Mendes da Rocha was only 30 when he built his first major building, the Paulistano Athletic Club, in his hometown, São Paulo, Brazil. A giant concrete disk atop wedge-shaped struts of the same gutsy material, it looked like a spaceship ready to blast off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: How Deceptive Campaign Fund-Raising Ensnares Older People
description: Older Americans, a critical source of political donations, often fall victim to aggressive and misleading digital practices. A broad Times analysis points to the scope of the problem.
content: William W. Vaughan Jr. was a senior atmospheric scientist at NASA during the space race and later an accomplished academic, but as with so many aging Americans, time and technology had sapped him of some of his savvy, especially online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It Has Its Limits
description: Count yourself in on this tough puzzle from John Lieb and Brad Wilber.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I have a trainee in my day job right now whose rapid-fire questions remind me of a hungry baby bird, and I’ve become acutely aware of how hard it is to explain a lot of what I do. I assure you, it’s all extremely vital to the operation, but I’m at a loss when someone comes around and needs to know what it is, exactly. A lot of entries in this challenging puzzle ring that same bell — idioms, grammatical quirks, a slew of humorous references to fingers and toes — all fair fodder for a Saturday, many difficult to figure out (and some hard to explain to myself, frankly).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Amber Bracken
title: With Discovery of Unmarked Graves, Canada’s Indigenous Seek Reckoning
description: Two gruesome discoveries of what Indigenous groups say are the remains of hundreds of children have strengthened the groups’ resolve to hold the country accountable for a long-hidden brutal history.
content: MUSKOWEKWAN FIRST NATION, Saskatchewan — At age 6, Ken Thomas said he was put in a van, driven two hours from his home and dropped on the steps of the Muskowekwan Indian Residential School. The nuns immediately shaved off his braids, and he soon learned that whenever he spoke his Indigenous language they would wash out his mouth with soap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: British Health Minister, Matt Hancock, Quits After Social Distancing Furor
description: Mr. Hancock, who spearheaded the country’s pandemic response, was the latest member of the government to be accused of violating coronavirus restrictions.
content: LONDON — Britain’s embattled health minister, Matt Hancock, resigned on Saturday, a day after a tabloid newspaper published photos of him in a steamy embrace with one of his senior aides — an apparent violation of Britain’s social-distancing guidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘How Can You Hate Me When You Don’t Even Know Me?’
description: There's something to be said for talking, and listening, to even unreasonable antagonists.
content: One of the questions I’m asked most is: How do I talk to those on the other side of America’s political and cultural abyss? What can I say to my brother/aunt/friend who thinks Joe Biden is a socialist with dementia who stole the election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Gottlieb
title: Robert Gottlieb on the Man Who Saw America (And We Mean, All of It)
description: In 1947, the legendary journalist John Gunther published “Inside U.S.A.,” a best-selling 900-page portrait of the country. Robert Gottlieb revisits the book, revealing a reporter with an eagle eye and a limitless appetite for facts.
content: Almost 75 years ago John Gunther produced his amazing profile of our country, “Inside U.S.A.” — more than 900 pages long, and still riveting from start to finish. It started out with a first printing of 125,000 copies — the largest first printing in the history of Harper & Brothers — plus 380,000 more for the Book-of-the-Month Club. It was the third-biggest nonfiction best seller of 1947 (ahead of it, only Rabbi Joshua Loth Liebman’s “Peace of Mind” and the “Information Please Almanac”). It was a phenomenon, but not a surprise: Gunther’s first great success, “Inside Europe,” published in 1936, had helped alert the world to the realities of fascism and Stalinism; “Inside Asia” and “Inside Latin America” followed, with comparable success — all three of these books were among the top sellers of their year, as would be “Inside Africa” and “Inside Russia Today,” yet to come. His “Roosevelt in Retrospect” (1950) is one of the best political biographies I’ve ever come across, a mere 400 pages long and pure pleasure to read. Like “Inside U.S.A.,” it is out of print — please, American publishers, one of you make them reappear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Detroit Flooding: 50 Drivers Rescued and 350 Vehicles Damaged
description: Parts of Detroit got up to seven inches of rain. “This isn’t normal here,” an official said.
content: Up to seven inches of rain fell early on Saturday in parts of Detroit and Wayne County, Mich., stranding hundreds of vehicles on flooded freeways and prompting the rescue of about 50 drivers, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Giulia Heyward
title: Fire beneath the debris is hampering search efforts.
description: Smoke from a fire deep within the debris of the collapsed Champlain Towers South condominium in Surfside, Fla., has created severe difficulties for search and rescue workers, Mayor Daniella Levine Cava of Miami-Dade County said Saturday morning.
content: Smoke from a fire deep within the debris of the collapsed Champlain Towers South condominium in Surfside, Fla., has created severe difficulties for search and rescue workers, Mayor Daniella Levine Cava of Miami-Dade County said Saturday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: A Chat With Arika Okrent
description: In her new book, “Highly Irregular: Why Tough, Through and Dough Don’t Rhyme,” the linguist and author explains the oddities of the English language.
content: Join us here to solve Crosswords, The Mini, and other games by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Patricia Mazzei and Joseph B. Treaster
title: Anxious Residents of Sister Tower to Fallen Florida Condo Wonder: Stay or Go?
description: The partly collapsed Champlain Towers South scared people who live in Champlain Towers North. But no one has ordered them to evacuate — yet.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Philip Zyne peered over the balcony of his condo near Miami Beach around midday on Saturday and pointed to a large crack running in the parking lot below his unit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Royal Drama Unfolds in Court, but a Prince at the Center of It Is Absent
description: Two prominent figures are on trial in Jordan accused of plotting to destabilize the kingdom. One is an adviser to Saudi Arabia’s leader, and the Saudis have been trying to disrupt the trial.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — In a shabby state security court on the outskirts of the Jordanian capital, a highly unusual trial is unfolding that provides a rare glimpse into the kingdom’s fractured royal family, its tensions with more powerful neighbors in the region and its alliance with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanna Pearlstein, Rachel Lee Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: Coming Out in a Pandemic: ‘We Really Don't Have Time to Waste’
description: ‘In a time of total upheaval came the opportunity to affirm something beautiful and authentic.’
content: ‘In a time of total upheaval came the opportunity to affirm something beautiful and authentic.’
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $730,000 in California
description: A 1914 cottage in Sonoma, a bungalow in Oakland and a one-bedroom condominium in Santa Monica.
content: A 1914 cottage in Sonoma, a bungalow in Oakland and a one-bedroom condominium in Santa Monica.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Floyd Family Reacts to Derek Chauvin Sentencing
description: The family of George Floyd said the 22½-year sentence for the former police officer was not long enough but celebrated what they viewed as partial accountability.
content: The family of George Floyd said the 22½-year sentence for the former police officer was not long enough but celebrated what they viewed as partial accountability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Biden Tells Afghan President That Partnership ‘Is Not Ending’
description: President Biden on Friday hosted the president of Afghanistan, Ashraf Ghani, and said that despite the withdrawal of American forces, the U.S. would continue to offer security assistance and aid.
content: President Biden on Friday hosted the president of Afghanistan, Ashraf Ghani, and said that despite the withdrawal of American forces, the U.S. would continue to offer security assistance and aid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 26, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 26, 2021.
content: An article on Monday about parliamentary elections in Ethiopia misstated the time in November when Senator Chris Coons of Delaware warned Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia about the perils of using military force in Tigray. Senator Coons said he had spoken to Mr. Ahmed in late November, not early November.
source.name: The New York Times
